instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2289: What is A2289? A2289 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2020 with EMC 3456, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01987..
definitions.820-01987: What is 820-01987? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message:
Hi, got here a new problem case. Received it with only little info. little corrosion around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> Fixed it easy. Was booting fine but very slow hihg CPU usage while Idle. Checked all set sensors nothing missing or no high temps. After another cleaning with flux around the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Now won't boot. I checked all the power rails.

USB-C amp  20v up to 0,4a than steady 0,05a
All there even
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 1,8 v after 10 sec back to 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>

But no
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 0v

Checked for corrosion around <CHIP>U7220</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>. looks clean. 

What can It be?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message: Could it be in DFU? Did you try to revive it with AC2?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message: Check for knocked off components in the cleaned areas.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="Mortentoft, post: 90660, member: 28201"]
Could it be in DFU? Did you try to revive it with AC2?
[/QUOTE]
Was a good idea… to bad, not in DFU mode. Even when I put it in DFU mode restore did nothing…

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 90661, member: 682"]
Check for knocked off components in the cleaned areas.
[/QUOTE]
No knocked off parts looked reallly careful. But could it be something that was also the reason why the system was so slow. What can be the reason of a high indeling of the cpu?!?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message:
If all components in place, something reacted to heat applied.
Board had some problem already, if was slow.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message:
I think it has to be something to do with origin of the problem, system being slow and now there is no <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>... Maybe we can troubleshoot back. 

Where does <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> come from? <CHIP>U7220</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>. Both are supplied with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_HS_CPU</SIGNAL> 
What is needed for <CHIP>U7220</CHIP>/<CHIP>U7210</CHIP> to create <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>?? 

Could it be that only 1 Phase se was supplied before and that was the reason of the slow cpu? Not enough power? I can't find much about this subs that's whyI'm thinking out of the box...

This in advance

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message:
PCH/CPU and T2/BIOS are involved to generate CPU core voltage.
Is not just a simple enable signal...

Could you complete DFU restore?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message: No, DFU restore gave error… Can a bios Cause no CPU Core voltage? I read a lot about bios disruption. I‘ll try to reflash bios.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2289</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01987</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> was very slow now won't boot.
threads.message:
You can't flash BIOS; is secured into T2.
SoC ROM (<CHIP>U4770</CHIP>) is not BIOS, but sometime can prevent the board to work correctly; give it a try.
